pros: I can honestly say that my colleagues are fabulous, wonderful, smart, impressive  supportive people who I am proud to call my colleagues.
cons: The bureaucracy is mind-numbing, endless and counter-productive.  Constant re-inventing of the same wheels over and over, a general lack of communication, the need for a minimum of 3 to 5 people to sign-off on anything, and requirements that faculty fill-out or create many of the federal  forms required for grant proposals means that the University wastes time, labor and money at the speed of light.  It makes absolutely no fiscal sense to pay someone a faculty salary to do paperwork which could be completed by administrative staff.  The faculty are bad at it, and it takes time away from their main purpose - which is to teach and get grants to allow them to conduct research and train others to conduct research.  For a University which requires that a large component of faculty salary comes from soft-money/grants (from 40 to 75%), they sure do make it hard for faculty to do.  They are shooting themselves in the foot everyday because of it, with no hope of healing the wound.

pros:
Benefits are great, especially if you are single. 
Work environment is comfortable for the most part.
Diverse co workers are one of the best parts of the job. It definitely reflects the city of Houston because staff are from all cultures and walks of life.
cons:
Upper management can be very two faced. It really depends on who your supervisor is which can be a mixed bag.
Work politics are an issue at every job but there can be a problem with miscommunication and cattiness between supervisors. Two of my supervisors seemed to dislike each other and often gave conflicting information about the same projects or daily tasks making it difficult to know who to listen to. 
Pay is okay for someone starting out but the benefits make it comparable to other companies.
Parking is a nightmare and expensive. Take the metro to work if you can.
Construction is a constant issue and contributes to the issue of traffic.

job_title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track in Houston, TX
pros: All depends, if you are a technician, a post-doc, an assistant, benefits are good and work load is very low and no stress. However, if you are an assistant professor you have tremendous pressure by the greedy administrator that by the way are old faculty that have multiple positions, for example, the president of the university was the chairman of pediatrics and the for many years the dean of the medical school; others are full time professors, chairman of a large department, vice president of research and executive director of an institute and the list go on, just check by yourself.  For a start faculty there are really very few pros, low salary, high pressure by the administrators to get grants and if you are lucky and negotiated a start up package, the package is lower than average, and they just gave you an office and forget about you, no support, advice, etc. Your are on your own but you will be evaluated by your peers and criticised and compared against senior faculty.
cons: There are many, as I said before if you are not a faculty your will have a very low stress job with average benefits and salary but if you are a starting faculty you are doomed.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Working closely with professors allows you to absorb their knowledge. Opportunities to network with professors and others in academia and in industry. Flexible schedule to allow for time for research. Use this as an opportunity to learn a real skill or tool to put on your resume to make it easy to find a job in the future. Use this part-time position to work on your research or do an internship to gain real world experience. Some weeks you may only do a few hours of the professor's research and other times you are working very hard to help them to make their deadline and putting in time after hours. It all comes out evenly in the end.
cons: Contract is only good for 1 semester and the professor must invite you to renew it each semester. If professor is no longer funded, you may be out of a job unless you jump on to another professor's grant. Flexible schedule means you work on professor's schedule and timetable; some weeks you may only do a few hours of the professor's research and other times you are working very hard to help them to make their deadline and putting in time after hours.

pros: none. they have a lot of position to later move forward
cons: bureaucracy everywhere, very low salary, look somewhere else

pros:
-Work was truly cutting edge
-Benefits were decent, standard for a state job
-People I worked with were generally nice
cons:
-My boss was incredibly unethical, moody and incompetent. One minute he was laughing and joking around, the next he was cussing me out. Some of the things that occurred there were the most unethical things I have ever seen. This was a major contributing factor to my departure.
-Pay was too low. This was also a major contributing factor to my departure. 
-The bus system was not efficient at all. Logistics in general here were a major issue. Parking was horrible as well.
-Training was non-existent. I was expected to figure exceedingly complex things out on my own and any failure was met with a severe tongue lashing.
-Perceived lack of funding held up critical work, which then got "scooped" by another institution. Actually, the funding was there, but my boss didn't want to spend it on doing the project.
-Food was expensive and not very good.  
-I was on call 24/7/365, and was told I could not go more than a couple hundred miles from Houston. Without on call compensation.

pros: Vacation and sick time accrue every month. You can roll over amounts of each according to how long you've been employed. All different types of clinics, so you're helping a wide range of people. Benefits/Insurance is dang good. Employees are generally nice.
cons: No innovation, no care to be efficient, ideas are shot down due to old policy and unwillingness to change. They will sure change everything though if it means bringing in a big name doctor to the establishment. They'll pay them high 6 figures  for minimal clinic hours and then tell me at the end of the year that there will be no merit raises (max 4%) because it's not in the budget. If you don't negotiate well upon hiring, you will be stuck at the bottom of the totem pole unless upper management has a thing for you or you transfer departments.

review_title: Working for UT Health is disappointing on the good days, and depressing most other times, especially lately.
pros:
The health benefits are top-notch (though I hear that is changing due to budget constraints).
Management is very sympathetic to leave-requests.
There are regular opportunities for advancement (good in the short view).
cons:
Management appears to be untrained, formally.
Budget cuts and "restructuring" are rampant throughout all departments.
All non-essential "perks" have been done away with (ie. cell phone supplements, catered meetings, holiday parties, etc.)
Pay raises have been halted for at least 3 years.
Workloads are increasing steadily while resources are not.

pros: Loved helping my patients, just wished we would work together as a tam
cons: LOTS of cons!  I have never been so demoralized and degraded as working for this one doctor.  She brought in the grants - I saw most of the patients...and what made matters worse- she never checked my quota of reviews according to AMA rules.  She gave me great reviews until I complained of her yelling mouth of obscenities to all our team members, and then she started saying that she was worried that I could be killing her patients...when I tried to talk to admin it was basically be quiet and shut up.  I loved my patients - it was so hard to leave.  But verbal abuse is a lot at this place....I thought that went out in the 1900s!

job_title: Teaching Assistant, Division of Biostatistics in Houston, TX
pros: As a graduate student, having the TA job is really helpful since I don't work outside of this job and my classes. A major benefit for me is having the health insurance covered by the school, since that can be quite expensive. The hours are flexible, so I do my work on my own time for the class I TA for. You get some experience teaching and tutoring students outside of class as well.
cons: I wasn't sure whether the insurance information would be different from semester to semester, so I had to purchase the student plan to remove the registration hold. Then I had to get a refund for the student plan since I was on the employee plan as a TA. This is only a possible con for students since the TA position isn't really finalized until after the new semester starts, and registration occurs at the end of the previous semester.

job_title: Research Assistant NC in Houston, TX
pros: Offers really good benefits. Holiday schedule is good. This is a good place to start fresh out  of school and get experience. Flexible schedule.
cons: A lot of politics. no room for growth. low salaries. Would not recommend staying here for more than 1 year. Unless you are planning on staying in academics  there is nothing that will be good enough. A bunch of professors covering each other's backs.

review_title: Great place to get a Science Education!
pros:
- A great place with great people to work with and learn from
- Talented faculty 
- World class research facilities 
- UTHealth is surrounded by other world class research institute (Baylor, Rice, Methodist) which makes for very conductive environment for collaborative research 
- Excellent benefits
cons:
- The pay rate for graduate research assistants is a little low for the amount of work they do and the amount of education they hold. 
- Parking within in the medical center is very expensive.

review_title: Great Experience but alot of work
pros: You get to work with some of the best doctors in their field. There is a very diverse workforce and the institution as a whole employs personnel with years of experience and who are resourceful.
cons: A majority of the administrative support or clerical positions in research operations are dual or even triple assignments.  Most have a very large workload that is usually spread out amongst departments for the same position at a pharma company or CRO.

job_title: Senior Coder in San Antonio, TX
pros: Great benefits- TRS retirement, great PTO, Sick leave, Personal leave. Great accommodations.
cons: Coders do not have the opportunity to work remotely.

pros: The UTHealth faculty have been very supportive of my research interests and accomplishments. I highly recommend networking at UTHealth by engaging with individuals or labs from all the Schools that make up the UTHealth system.
cons: The UTHealth campus and community is very large which is both good and bad. On the plus side, it is a great organization to really branch out and meet great mentors (networking is key!). On the downside, unless you make an effort to engage with the community you may isolate yourself or feel a little lost.  As long as you remain engaged with the community you will ensure a successful career at UTHealth!

pros: Great colleagues, excellent benefits, decent pay.
cons: Nurse Practitioners and Physician Assistants are not valued in this company. If you expect to make all the providers have almost the same responsibilities but with less than half the pay and no bonuses and other extra perks, it isolates a group and causes a resentment, which will push an employee categorized in that group to look for employment elsewhere.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: I've been able to work with renowned experts who are passionate, respectful, cordial and knowledgeable who are doing work to improve health care.  The people I've worked with have all showed an interest in helping me develop my knowledge and understanding. The work is something I believe is important and that I find interesting, too. I feel fortunate to have the job.
cons: The job matches my expectations for a graduate research assistant position. IMHO, a GRA position is not a career-type job, it is a way to have experience-based learning that can lead to professional opportunities.

pros: Some of the faculty are really great people.  Not sure that is a sufficient reason to do research here.
cons: This institution is heavily weighed down by administration, who in general wield much power but aren't motivated to work efficiently since it is a state-run institution.  Sadly, this is reflected in the quality of research compared to more influential institutions in the Texas Med. Center such as Baylor College of Medicine, Rice University, and Methodist Hospital.  While there is a lot of great research going on here by faculty, administrative procedures and policies hinder efficiency and cross-institutional collaboration.

review_title: Excellent and talented co-workers and management.  Great environment.
job_title: Network Security Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: Surrounded by outstanding and skilled people.  Pays well.  Ability to get your hand on a large variety of technical tools.  Unlimited SANS training.  Suprisingly very un-bureaucratic for a state institution.  Results based work not encumbered by useless policy, this speaks volumes for IT Security leadership and the trust the institution places in them,
cons: They stick all IT folks in a windowless basement.  Pretty depressing physcial environment.

job_title: Revenue Cycle Management in Houston, TX
pros: Healthcare Benefits, Retirement Benefits, Pay, Vacation time, Sick time, Holidays off.  Growth opportunity can be good too.
cons: Several people in Leadership positions are not qualified by way of experience and educations but got the position due to knowing some higher up.  I feel this puts those at the mid level and supporting staff levels at a disadvantage of growing professionally as well as make for a low morale department.

pros: You'll work with some of the brightest and most passionate people in the medical field! Human Resources in particular has very much of a family feel which is a refreshing change from other places I've worked.
cons: Career paths for all disciplines is an area that requires further attention when thinking long term for the organization. The organization has bright individuals who have much to contribute.  It is necessary for the leadership to recognize and nurture them so that they can reach their full potential.

review_title: Great learning environment....a lot of program development and advancement is need.
pros: Benefits are a plus. State of Texas job. 8 to 5 job. Tuition reimbursement is offered.
cons: Safety is a challenging topic to preach in an academic and research institution. Money always seems to be an issue for everything. 0-3% raises annually if that. No advancement in positions. Once a specialist always a specialist.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Houston, TX
pros: It is an ok workplace, city environment, if you have a car, you can get around. If you like south city, this could be a good choice.
cons: A lot of policies and bureaucracy. Pace is slow, everything is slower than eastern coast US. Houston is very hot and humid in summer, just be prepared. If you like hot weather, it may be fine for you. The labs have very cold air conditioning. The research environment is just ok, it works like a company.

pros: Management is usually flexible. The environment is very professional.  The talent hired is usually very knowledgeable in their field which helps the flow of business. Positions are very stable.
cons: Pay is reasonable but not very competitive.  Not many growth opportunities.  Benefits are great for a single person/average for a family. There is no stipend for parking like other TMC employers

review_title: Complex mix of institutes competing for resources.
pros:
many excellent colleagues
variety of core facilities for research
good benefits: health insurance, retirement, vacation time, sick leave
good programs for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows
open for international students, researchers and physicians
cons:
lots of bureaucracy
lack of leadership and resources (as state funding decreases, making/saving money became top priority)
salaries are low (except for some top departments, centers)
IT management is constantly changing, doesn't keep up with the advanced technology

review_title: High risk to your professional growth.
job_title: Senior, Talent Acquisition Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: The people are very friendly.  Great benefits. Well organized.
cons: High turn-over rate, especially for veterans. Quick to fire without warning or putting personnel on a professional growth plan. The organization's management isn't serious about keeping those they hire.

pros: Benefits are great and work schedule is pretty flexible which is always a plus. Shuttle service also provided to be able to move around multiple sites which is also good.
cons: There's just not enough room for growth. Severely under paid which makes life a little hard. Make sure you really like what you do so you're not miserable. Professors are so engulfed with their research and expect their staff to bend over backwards.

review_title: I am current employee and have been with UTHealth for 1.5 years.
pros: Great growth opportunity if you are a hard worker.  If you think you are getting into a safe government job and don't have to excel to keep your job, this isn't the place for you.  UTHealth has high standards and everyone expects their colleague to pull their own weight.
cons: Salary increases are restrained so your financial growth will be steady but slow.

pros: Access to TMC. Full tuition, travel, books, insurance and editing support. Gym access as well. Great faculty and mentors. Good opportunities for networking and collaboration with other research centers in the area
cons: It is very expensive to park in the medical center. Student housing has been opened up to anyone in the medical center, so there are long waitlists.

pros: Benefits and  job stability, most co-workers are very helpful. Majority of the teaching faculty are awesome.
cons: Managers are clickish, unable to speak with any level of management in my department or HR confidentially without the party being name knowing exactly what was said. Then you being called into their office immediately after. No career advancement opportunities in each department.

review_title: The best job that I had in the last 6 Years. Flexible, well paid, miles etc
pros: Well paid,   clear schedules, everybody  where very nice. 15 us per hour is very decent.
cons: Down times  like May, June, Nov and December but really depends on the project.  and of course projects ends like mine did.  Also even every  week by week the hours can change dramatically depending of  how many interview they can schedule.

review_title: Great relationships with colleagues and students
job_title: Assistant Professor Nursing in Houston, TX
pros: UTHealth has a large network with a lot of influence in the Texas Healthcare community.
cons: Little to no protection for non-tenure track professors. Academic success of every student is not always taken into consideration when program decisions are made by administration.

pros: Friendly, highly collaborative, productive environment. Great mentors, highly motivated people, no cut-throats, good benefits, job security.
cons: Not fast paced, some lack of organization, salaries are not competitive, most positions are transitory, and the 60% of the population is fleeting.

job_title: Coordinator of Admission in Brownsville, TX
pros: Flexible schedule, great benefits and retirement plan, decent people.  Work life was good, not great
cons: At a state school everyone is treated the same.  This goes equally for the idiots and the work horses.  Salary is low, but you know that going in.  There is zero advancement to the upper levels as university careers are based on degrees/education and NOT actual experience or ability to perform at a job.

job_title: Systems and Applications Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: Big University with all of the pros that come with that kind of work place. Good benefits and time off. Stable. Pay was sub par, but the benefits outweigh that aspect.
cons: Not particularly exciting environment to work in. Pretty bureaucratic and formal. Not a great deal of access to career development opportunities.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: UTHouston is located in the Texas medical center, the largest medical center in the world an is home to several prestigious research institutions and hospitals. the exposure to research and academia you will get is unparalleled by any other place. If you are in basic sciences or medical field, this is the place to be.
cons: Great institution, but lacks visibility and recognition in terms of the work they do. Need some good public relations.

review_title: A good place to be if research is what you are looking for !
pros:
Great mentors
Being in the heart of Texas Medical Center
Great track record of publications
Their tution reimbursement program is good
cons:
Your growth really depends on who you work for
Accountability is an issue with some tenured faculty - they are just cruising

pros: Great Benefits! Some areas have flexible scheduling.  Work Life balance is important.  There are many locations to choose from.
cons: Medical Center Traffic!  Expensive Parking!  Some areas have no room for professional development or growth.  There is no such thing as an annual raise or cost of living raise.

pros: As a scientist, I feel UTHealth is in the cutting edge of medical research, with multiple research groups and helpful staff.
cons: One of the problems of any big university is the difficulty of interdisciplinary collaborations. These collaborations are vital for new discoveries.

pros: UTHealth had some great people who work in research. The training in my department was great. As a part-time employee, they were able to work with school schedule. The research projects paid for mileage driven when going to different testing sites.
cons: The job can be demanding of your time at times. There was plenty of traveling using your own car. Work hours were not guaranteed each week.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Houston, TX
pros: Good benefits, lots of support from the training departments, great location, many opportunities to learn from other insitutions.
cons: No social environment, very limited collaboration within the university, poor retention benefits, lack of ameneties (not even free coffee), more focused on staff retention than research talent retention.

job_title: Research Assistant Professor in Houston, TX
pros: Great state of Texas benefits. Flexible Schedule.
cons: Low salary, high stress environment where creativity is not appreciated. This sort of obtuse approach often leads to disgruntled postdocs and research staff.

job_title: Senior Research Fellow in Houston, TX
pros: People are so nice and collaborative.  They understand each other very well.  Time is very flexible in both work and life.
cons: Salary is soft money. You need to prepare for your future career if you have a big family.

job_title: Research Assistant II in San Francisco, CA
pros: It's a good starter job if you like research and do not want to go straight into grad school. They set up a retirement fund once you being working there
cons: Pay is not as high as employees would like. Might work over time but no extra pay is received for it.

pros: Great benefits for vacation, health insurance and sick time. The employees there are decent and overall want the best for the institution.
cons: Management plays favorites at times. Unfortunately, this can spill over into drama in the office and with employees. Besides that, there are no complaints.

pros: The university provides excellent health benefits and good security. There are excellent seminars for personal development, including an exceptional women in leadership series started a few years ago.
cons: Among my friends and colleagues, it's relatively difficult to identify a path to professional advancement.

pros:
I like the Supportive environment
I was attracted by the amount of cutting edge research
It's Part of UT System
Positive environment Great employee relations
cons: Difficult to say, I guess perhaps limitations of the academic salaries and limited resources associated with being at state vs. private entity.

review_title: Helpful to build relationships, but not very challenging
pros: When work is slow, you can continue working on your studies/homework assignments, etc which is helpful as a student. You get to know a lot of the faculty, and can build relationships with future colleagues and/or employers.
cons: Not very challenging work, can get monotonous. No opportunity for direct advancement or expansion of responsibilities.

review_title: Great place to start a research oriented Career. Get to work with the best scientists.
job_title: Research Scientist I in Houston, TX
pros: Good research atmosphere, Most of the PI have good funding or departmental backing.
cons:
Low pay. Infact with the amount of hours an RA works, the wage is less than minimum/hr.
Parking is expensive.
No bonus like MD Anderson.

pros: Work is pretty chill for the most part. Can be very laid back especially at night. As long as you handle your business everything is cool. Benefits are top of the line.
cons: Scheduling is the absolute worst. Your schedule will be inconsistent. Get ready to be working every weekend as well. Pay is not the best but it's decent for what you are doing.

pros: Good retirement health benefits but I understand this changes 1/1/2018.  Suspect hiring of good employees in the future will become more difficult for UTHealth.
cons: Poor advancement within the organization.  Raises within the department have been level for the past ten years.

pros: Professional development opportunities are available. Work with great students and professors. Making a difference in our community and the world.
cons: Pay is not necessarily competitive for Austin. Education and research funding has has been dramatically cut since the Trump administration took over.

review_title: In general a nice research institute
pros: Opportunities to work with a variety of labs with different expertise, good employee benefits (medical care, vacation days and so on).
cons: Sometimes the administrative part could be very slow and might take a long time to get paperwork done such as VISA processing for international employees

pros: Amazing benefits, great resources for everything you could need to do your job, friendly people, and you get a subsidy to ride the rail and the bus.
cons: Communication is terrible between the management team and everyone else is awful. I've had to teach myself everything since nobody could be bothered to talk to me.

pros: Actual job, helping others,  meeting new people, benefits, break time and lunch time, timeoff allotment
cons: Department Level Management could be retrained or restaffed

job_title: Research Assistant I in Houston, TX
pros: Nice working environment and great atmosphere.  Holiday parties and cultural fairs.  Not in the middle of the Texas Medical Center so it is less chaotic.
cons: Parking of course is pricy and there are graduate students everywhere.

pros: Heavy focus on career and professional development encouragement and support from management.  Relaxed working environment with a great office atmosphere.
cons: The campus is very spread out and a position that requires movement between buildings can be very challenging.  Things have grown with the addition of clinical facilities

pros: I had lot of autonomy to do my best and learned so many different aspects of research (administration and grants management)  when working as a research coordinator. The medical benefits provided by UTHealth is awesome!
cons: There are many layers you have to go through when it comes to approving expenses

job_title: Data Systems Coordinator in San Antonio, TX
pros: The people you work with are great.  It's a relatively low pressure environment and as long as daily jobs are done, you'll be fine.
cons: Leadership has constant political issues with one another.  It seems UTHSCSA is always contracting or expanding.

job_title: Assistant Director in San Antonio, TX
pros: Growth minded organization looking to improve market share and improve lives in the San Antonio area
cons: Developing organization sometimes struggles with an accurate understanding of its perception in the community. Lack of promotional opportunities.

review_title: Excellent benefits make up for quite a bit of bad
job_title: Senior Administrative Manager in Houston, TX
pros: Exceptional employment benefits, job security, excellent executive leadership, growth opportunities, good work-life balance
cons: Poor and/or ineffective senior/middle management structure, below average market pay, difficult to transfer into new opportunities, organizational culture is heavily skewed towards physician favor and influence at the expense of administrative staff

review_title: Very good so far, started off part time and landed the first job that I was fit to qualify for full time
pros: Very good benefits, nice people to work with, pay always on time
cons: Work life/balance disrupted HR needs to be more effective

review_title: UTHealth is an amazing company with excellent benefits and a flexible work environment.
job_title: Clinical Systems Administrator in Houston, TX
pros: State benefits are hard to beat and managers generally maintain a healthy work life balance for their employees.
cons: Pay is a bit low compared to other employers in the medical center, but it's offset by great benefits.

review_title: Grad school is what you make it
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros:
-One of the best places to do cancer research
-State of the art facilities 
-Seemingly endless collaboration opportunities
-Many scientific and career development seminars
-Graduate school is very supportive of the students
cons:
-Multiple campuses so things feel a bit segregated
-Grad school is tough work, be prepared to have a limited social life

review_title: Overall my experience has been good.
pros: Great benefits and decent working environments.
cons: Upward mobility is not an easy accomplishment, investing great time an patience will allow you one day to progress.

pros: There are isolated islands of competency. In comparison, good benefits. If you want to be lazy and accept that you have to play the game, this is the place for you.
cons: It feels like the management appoints people according to their personal preferences and not according to the applicant's professional accomplishments. People tend to make themselves look better by talking behind the back of others to make them look worse. Hierarchy is everything.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Houston has many opportunities, it is a growing city with booming economy.
cons:
The pay are average and students are too many here, so the altitudes of some staff are not so kind as they are squeezed by the amount of workload.

Dont confuse UTHealth Houston with MD Anderson nearby.

review_title: A very positive, nurturing learning experience.
pros: Heavy focus on academic qualifications, support for studies, work is strongly correlated to science.
cons: Rigid structures can sometimes promote bureaucracy, clients are student researchers.

review_title: Shining star of the Texas Medical Center
pros: Development Office has done an incredible job of raising funds from private philanthropic sources to advance the goals of the institution.
cons: So many wonderful researchers it’s hard to know what everyone is doing throughout the organization.

pros: Flexible hours, good pay for a student, great learning experience and resume building, free shuttle to work
cons: Can be a little slow if working on a grant funded project, but I had a high quality team who was great to work with

job_title: Senior Executive Assistant in Houston, TX
pros:
-Outstanding benefits-health insurance premium for employees paid by employer, employer matches retirement
-Very strong administrative leadership
-University embraces diversity
cons:
-Quality of position depends largely on department
-Opportunities for growth depend largely on department
-Availability of tuition reimbursement depends on department funding rather than University funding

job_title: Instructional Technology Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Tasks are routine-based and not challenging at all. Relaxed office environment and friendly employees. Work under no competition and no pressure.
cons: Boring atmosphere, almost no humor in the office. People rarely think out of the box; lack of creativity and energy. High turnover rate. Low wage.

pros: Helping UT Health students with their educational classes to become Medical Assistants,  Nurses. Or Doctors
cons: Very casual part-time position. Do not work a minimal amount of hrs to have benefits.

pros: The wonderful staff I work with are always conscious of the fact that I am a student first. They allow me to work independently with support as needed.
cons: The work can be boring every now and then, but such is the life of a GA.

pros:
Good pay and benefits!
Flexibility with family issues
cons:
Terrible leadership
Lack of direction
Many irregularities and violations of policy happen all the time and you get punished if you bring it up. 
Glass ceiling to executive or faculty positions for people of color

job_title: Senior SPECIALIST-NETWORK SUPPORT in Houston, TX
pros: Great  retirement and holiday time off
cons: Pay is on the lower end with employer choice of annual merrit pay raise. most of the company's money is spent on projects.

job_title: Front End Web Developer in Houston, TX
pros:
Great Environment
Amazing co-workers
Learning environment
cons: Remote option would be nice, more flexibility in regards to work time....at times hard to leave work to go do things

review_title: Professional with high standards all the way...and I was only a Lab Tech!
pros: Located in the Medical Center!
cons: Dated equipment and super-tight research budgets. Never saw a dollar wasted in ANY of the labs. Very budget conscious. Wish they would increase pay for Graduate Students. Long hours.

review_title: If your lazy this is the place to be.
pros: Great benefits, pay is ok, but needs to have better annual increase.
cons: They punish the hardworkers and the lazy workers get away with murder.

pros: Very good reputation in the research field.  Funding was adequate for research goals.
cons: Limited salary increases because raises are completely based on title.  In order to increase pay, you must be promoted to next salary title at some point.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Houston, TX
pros: decent benefits with good vacation time. The work culture is better than other places I have worked.
cons: High cost of parking. Difficult to get to work in traffic. I would recommend living near and using the metro or biking.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: fully paid health insurance, pension, low overtime
cons: job duties, raises, promotion opportunities are entirely manager driven and there are huge discrepancies between departments and job levels, processes are outdated and communication is poor

review_title: UTHealth is a good place for doing your PhD
pros: Graduate research assistant (GRA) position usually available for PhD student; The pay is good in terms of a part-time student; Insurance is very good
cons: As an academia job, it depends on the funding of the professor who hire you

review_title: I find that senior employees are more incline to be watchdogs instead of resources.
pros: You are in the center of TMC; surrounded by some of the best phyician in the country.
cons: Finding parking and the cost of parking i find is the worst.

pros: The benefits are great here! For example I have allergies and my allergy shots are 100% free with my UTH health plan/insurance which is very rare because allergy shots are very expensive!
cons: I wish parking was a little bit more affordable

pros: I LOVED the culture at UTHealth and the people I worked with! Great work life balance and I felt supported. Made friends for life here!
cons: Career progression can be a challenge and the pace can be slow because it’s higher education.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Located in the largest medical center in the world, a lot of exposure to medical and research areas, six schools in different health related directions
cons: As a graduate research assistant here, my salary is very low.

pros: Management takes care of employees.  Benefits are very good.  Opportunities for advancement are available.
cons: Working for State institution can be challenging.  Over the top rules and regulations and red tape to get even the simplest things done.

review_title: Great atmosphere for graduate research/teaching assistant students
job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Wonderful professors and students to work with! Flexible work schedule.
cons:
Limited and expensive parking! 
Wages are relatively low, but not bad.

pros: The benefits provided by University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston are amazing even for part time employees.
cons: Coming from a regional campus, coordination with the main campus management was difficult and took longer than usual.

pros: 1 day vacation and sick leave per month, good insurance, good administration for the dental school
cons: My PI is not a good person to work for, the website is a bit difficult to navigate

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Great training in scientitic method and to become a principal investigator in academia
cons: Not enough training on alternative career paths.

pros: Good benefits, lots of positions, large city.
cons: All the bads you can count as a postdoc: low pay, working in weekends, no extra time pay, stressful working environment and promotion with no chance

pros: Good experience for a social worker who loves behavioral health.
cons: High turnover, few raises, no self care culture, poor management, lots of paperwork, difficult to get time off.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: UTHealth offers a great learning and networking environment to employees across board
cons: There may not be readily available/accessible information  on employee development programs

review_title: Good Company with great coworkers but shady division heads
pros: Co-workers are amazing, PTO, benefits, salary and flexibility
cons: some division heads are corrupt, mean and unprofessional

pros: diversity, flexibility, laid-back atmosphere, friendly colleagues
cons: no transparency in hiring, static/stale culture, little innovation/research, incompetitive

pros: Good benefits! Flexible work - experience varies based on professor who employs you, but i lucked out. Was able to save hours up to take maternity leave, and work flexibly after.
cons: Not great pay for what you are doing.

review_title: Not a place for career growth
pros: Free medical benefit, 15 days holiday time off, 13 sick days off and at least 12 vacation days per year.
cons: Routine work everyday. There is no place for promotion or learn new skills. Low base salary.

pros: Enriching atmosphere in the department between professors, postdocs and students.
cons: Very few opportunities for advancement from the postdoc or junior faculty positions, low pay.

pros: Maintain and stabilize in a secure professional environment to extend my skills and allow me an opportunity for future advancement.
cons: none job was great i enjoyed it.

pros: The University setting is friendly oriented.
cons: The department I worked for was very controlling.  It wasn't a pleasant place to work.  The administration has no interest in the well-being of its staff.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Houston, TX
pros: location; diversity; strong and competent Postdoctoral Office; largest Medical Center in the USA; tons of Seminars for career development around campus
cons: Postdoc position sallary is low compared to other universities; no local grant system for Postdocs

review_title: Wonderful place to work during graduate school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Flexible working hours, friendly working environment, able to apply what one learns during class to work, reasonable pay
cons: I really didn't experience any negatives while I was working as a GRA

pros: flexible working hours. open environment to learn new stuff.
cons: scientific project is bad in terms of scoping. Some researchers are very critical and conservative. Productivity is not efficient like industry.

review_title: UT health is a good institution.
pros: the international office has been very helpful. good IT support and security management.
cons: Local scientific research culture is conservative, creativity is discouraged.

job_title: Dental Assistant I in Houston, TX
pros: Great benefits, meeting new people, refresher on things you might of forgot from when you started
cons: Coworkers that have been there more than 2 plus yrs. , it's not what you know, its who you know

pros: Lots of different medical specialties to learn from and be a part of current clinical care and research too.
cons: A very large institution that doesn't always realize the role and impact of genetic counselors

job_title: Executive Assistant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Benefits--Health 100% covered by company and low cost dental and vision.  They cover up to $20,000 AD&D and many other benefits.
cons: Depends on what department you work for.

pros: Dedicated to providing world-class health care and health care education.
cons: It's a public institution, so budget restraints are real.

pros: Good for administrative work. Collaborative research environment.
cons: Not good for internationals. Employees are not valued. The worst international office staff. Unprofessional and inefficient.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros:
Not pushy environment.
Freedom to choose the field of interest.
Wide variety of big data resources.
cons: You will learn by doing projects. If you are not self motivated you will not learn much.

job_title: Research Assistant I in Houston, TX
pros:
Good benefits - including extra holiday time when facilities are closed.
Flexible scheduling - depending on PI
Friendly work culture
Good communication
cons:
Must pay for parking within Texas medical center. 
Paid time-off accrued over time.

pros: Layback atmosphere. Many GA positions are available.
cons: Limited research opportunities, focus only on obesity, physical activity and smoking. The biostatistician instructor is very unfriendly and not very helpful. Luck of professional epidemiological staff.

pros: easy going staff, very energetic
cons: decrepit facilities, dirty, repairs very slow, old, old research labs

pros: Good benefits, flexible schedule, lots of employee events
cons: Salary lower than private institutions, but, one must already know that if you're going to work for a public institution

pros: Working with people with mental illness is a real passion for me.
cons: The downside is how revolving the door is and patients constantly returning.

pros: Great set of people to work with. The Math department was new so it was being developed as I came in.
cons: There were not many jobs at the time I was working with them.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: The employees are nice and my employer had an open door policy
cons: Very little compensation for work done

pros: Good life situation, good friends.
cons: You don't move from the position you have even with expertise.... I been told I'll get a raise I've 1.5 years I'm still waiting

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Houston, TX
pros: UTHealth promotes employee work/life balance for at least non-medical employee. The institution offers significantly more PTO and Sick days.
cons: I've not encountered any cons with working at UTHealth.

pros: Collegial, entry level experience, flexible
cons: Seemed to lack continuous improvement, staff development in a formal sense.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Houston, TX
pros: Friendly environment. Supportive educators. Great place for state of the art research
cons: None I have experienced so far

job_title: Research Coordinator I in Houston, TX
